dataIdInfo.idPurp: This is the amplitude image for the reference granule from a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the calibrated radiometric backscatter in sigma-nought power. The image is terrain corrected using a geometric correction, but is not radiometrically corrected. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).
dataIdInfo.idAbs:
This is the amplitude image for the reference granule from a pair of Sentinel-1 SLC granules, processed using GAMMA software. The pixel values indicate the calibrated radiometric backscatter in sigma-nought power. The image is terrain corrected using a geometric correction based on the reference DEM, but is not radiometrically corrected. It is a 32-bit float GeoTIFF projected to WGS 84 / UTM zone 18N, and has a pixel spacing of 80 m. It was processed from the SLC using 20x4 looks (20 looks in the range direction and 4 looks in the azimuth direction).

Reference Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20181008T230552_20181008T230619_024051_02A0D6_7CE3

Secondary Scene: S1A_IW_SLC__1SDV_20181125T230551_20181125T230619_024751_02B91E_6F46

Processing Date/Time: 2021-11-01T01:11:17+00:00

The amplitude, or backscatter intensity, indicates how much of the sent signal returns to the sensor. This amplitude product has been terrain corrected, but not radiometrically corrected, and indicates the backscatter of the reference granule only. To compare amplitude between the granules used in this interferogram, consider ordering On Demand Radiometric Terrain Corrected (RTC) products for the two images used in the InSAR pair. The radiometric correction normalizes the backscatter based on the area contributing to the signal, which is particularly important in areas with rugged terrain. Refer to ASF's RTC Product Guide for more information about On Demand RTC products.

Because of the range of values present in power scale intensity datasets, the image may appear very dark when first displayed. Consider setting the layer symbology to Stretched - Standard Deviations (choose a number (n) that works best for your particular dataset; the ArcGIS default of n: 2 or 2.5 will improve the display, but other values may give a better visualization) to provide better contrast.

Refer to ASF's InSAR Product Guide for more information about On Demand InSAR products.

The Sentinel-1A satellite was launched April 3, 2014, and the Sentinel-1B satellite was launched April 25, 2016. The satellites each have a 12-day repeat cycle. More information about the mission is available at https://sentinels.copernicus.eu/web/sentinel/missions/sentinel-1.

Additional information about Sentinel-1 data, imagery, tools and applications is available at https://asf.alaska.edu/data-sets/sar-data-sets/sentinel-1.
dataIdInfo.idCredit:
When using this data as an image in a publication such as journal papers, articles, presentations, posters, and websites, please include the following credit with the image (portions in square brackets are optional):
[InSAR product processed by ]ASF DAAC HyP3 2021[ using GAMMA software]. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2018, processed by ESA.
When using this data in a manuscript and/or crediting datasets used for analysis, an acknowledgement including the software versions may be appropriate:
ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701. Contains modified Copernicus Sentinel data 2018, processed by ESA.
For more information on citing the dataset, please refer to the README file distributed with this product.

Consts.useLimit: There are no restrictions on the use of this data, but it must be acknowledged or cited as listed in the credits.

dataIdInfo.envirDesc: This product was generated by ASF DAAC HyP3 2021 using the hyp3_gamma plugin version 5.1.1 running GAMMA release 20210701.

dataLineage.statement:
The amplitude map is generated by GAMMA's multi_S1_TOPS program (called from the SLC_copy_S1_fullSW program), the output of which is a mosaicked multilook intensity (MLI) image. This is called immediately prior to interferogram creation.
For a detailed description of InSAR processing using GAMMA software, refer to the readme file included with the product package.
